item.title: Resident Evil Requiem Will Terrify From Multiple Camera Angles
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/resident-evil-requiem-will-terrify-from-multiple-camera-angles/1100-6532355/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Resident Evil Requiem will feature both first-person and third-person camera angles. Players will be able to switch between camera angles at any time within the game by pausing and changing the perspective.

Camera angles have been a huge part of Resident Evil's evolution. The original game and its sequel featured fixed camera angles, simulating security cameras viewing the action from a static position. Resident Evil 4 was the first game to switch to a dynamic, over-the-shoulder camera angle.

Resident Evil 4 was a gigantic hit, both in 2005 and each subsequent time the game was re-released, and remakes of Resident Evil 2 and 3 launched with dynamic, third-person camera angles in 2019 and 2020. The Resident Evil 2 remake has sold over 15 million copies since then, making it the third-most-successful games in Capcom's history.

Resident Evil 7: Biohazard and Resident Evil Village switched to a first-person camera angle, providing more intimate scares and claustrophobic action. Resident Evil Village went on to sell over 11 million copies since launching in 2021, proving that fans would eat up the scares Capcom provided no matter the camera angle.

We played Requiem for a short time and came away with more questions than answers, leaving us hungry for the full experience. Resident Evil Requiem is set to launch on February 26, 2026.

item.title: Hearthstone Lost City Of Un'goro Card Reveal: Demon Hunter Quest Unleashes The Swarm
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/hearthstone-lost-city-of-ungoro-card-reveal-demon-hunter-quest-unleashes-the-swarm/1100-6532266/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

For the next Hearthstone expansion, we're going back to the Lost City of Un'goro with another swashbuckling adventure. And since any such adventure needs an angry swarm of stinging insects, we have the Demon Hunter quest. With the Unleash the Colossus quest, you'll get regular tempo plays to inflict damage, followed by a reward that will make your future stings that much more deadly.

For those unfamiliar, Hearthstone quests are 1-mana spells that always start in your hand, and give you big rewards for completing their objectives. Demon Hunter's quest, Unleash the Colossus, challenges you to deal exactly two damage to an enemy on your turn, a whopping 15 times.

This may be an especially tricky proposition for Demon Hunter, whose hero power only deals one damage by default. But the full Demon Hunter quest package is built around giving you lots of options to deal exactly two damage, with a variety of new beasts to deliver the 2-damage stings. There's Gorishi Wasp that hits for two damage and gives you access to the Gorishi Stinger spell, which then delivers two damage twice more. Infestation, a new spell, also gives you Stingers. There's also the new Insect Claw weapon that gives you two charges of a two-damage strike, Gorishi Tunneler that acts as a two-for-one trigger of the quest by damaging both its target and the hero, and the 1-mana Silithid Grub with rush. Finally, while not a direct trigger for the quest, Silithid Queen synergizes well with the rest of the package by giving you big damage if you played a Beast the previous turn, thanks to its Kindred keyword.

So after delivering multiple stings against your opponent, you'll be rewarded with the Gorishi Colossus, a 5-mana 8/8 Beast that doubles your 2-damage attacks from that point on, for the rest of the game. That makes it very efficient at cutting down your opponent with lots of low-damage attacks, which Demon Hunter tends to excel at.

Hearthstone's Lost City of Un'goro expansion launches on July 8. Pre-purchases are available now. The regular bundle ($50) includes 60 packs, two random legendary cards, and a Spiritsinger Umbra card back. The Mega Bundle ($80) has 80 packs, 10 golden packs, one random Signature card, one random golden legendary card, four tavern tickets, and the Spiritsinger Umbra card back and Warlock hero skin. Finally, the Sequence Bundle ($60), available after purchasing the other two bundles, includes 10 more golden packs, 30 more card packs, and two random Signature legendary cards.

item.title: Hideo Kojima Doesn't Want His Company To Imitate Him After He's Gone
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/hideo-kojima-doesnt-want-his-company-to-imitate-him-after-hes-gone/1100-6532356/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Legendary video game developer Hideo Kojima hasn't made a secret about being gravely ill during the COVID-19 pandemic, and he worried that he would never finish another project. Kojima is still thinking about his mortality even after his recovery. However, he doesn't believe that Kojima Productions would survive if he instructs his successors to keep making games exactly the way he does.

"I am not going to pass the baton to anyone," Kojima told British GQ. "I will rather crush the baton… [Laughs] I don't need to give 'Hideo Kojima' to anyone. If I pass the baton to my staff and tell them to make things the same way I do, the company will not succeed and will go out of business."

When asked to elaborate on his statement, Kojima explained that creators who are inspired by him "received my small fire" and aren't trying to be exactly like him. He's happy to have influenced so many, but not eager to see anyone try to copy him exactly.

Earlier this year, Kojima disclosed that he filled a USB stick full of his ideas for video games to be used after his death. He referred to it as his "will," and stated that he would rather Kojima Productions continue making new games and new ideas rather than simply repeating the ones he's already made.

Kojima's next game, Death Stranding 2: On the Beach, will be released on PlayStation 5 on June 26. His other upcoming titles include the Xbox-exclusive OD and the spy-action game Physint. Kojima is also involved with the A24 Death Stranding movie, and he has expressed interest in directing his own original film.

item.title: Rainbow Six Siege Gets Huge Bump In Players After Siege X Launch
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/rainbow-six-siege-gets-huge-bump-in-players-after-siege-x-launch/1100-6532352/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Rainbow Six Siege's "most transformative" update in the game's 10-year history, Siege X, went live this week. It was seemingly embraced by players, as the game's Steam numbers jumped significantly following the debut of Siege X.

Data from SteamDB shows a massive spike in players on June 10 with the Siege X launch, peaking at around 142,000 concurrent players on Steam. It's still below Siege's all-time peak of 201,933 achieved on May 17, 2024, but it's an impressive gain all the same as people returned to Siege or tried it for the first time to check out the Siege X update and all of its new features and functionality.

Siege is currently inside the top five best-selling Steam games and inside the top 10 most-played games. Steam shares this data publicly, but Microsoft and Sony do not share similar sales or engagement data for the Xbox and PlayStation stores.

The Siege X update gives the game a makeover, of sorts, with better-looking graphics and improved sound. There is also brand-new 6v6 mode, Dual Front, among numerous other updates and improvements.

Rainbow Six Siege originally launched in 2015 and has been steadily supported and evolved over time with consistent updates. It reached 85 million players prior to the Siege X update.

item.title: Soccer Sensation Coming To Fortnite As Part Of A New Initiative From Epic Games
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/soccer-sensation-coming-to-fortnite-as-part-of-a-new-initiative-from-epic-games/1100-6532354/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Epic Games wants to enhance Fortnite's appeal in Korea and announced multiple collaborations, including a new skin for South Korean soccer star Son Heung-min in Fortnite. Heung-min was also added to PUBG Battlegrounds a few years ago and featured in EA Sports FC 25.

The Son Heung-min bundle will be released in the game store and includes his official uniform, the Forward Edge accessory that changes style according to time, the Goal Getter wrapping sheet with a soccer motif, and his iconic Snap Ceremony emote. All are on sale for a limited time from June 21-28.

In addition to Heung-min, Fortnite's music content has also been enhanced. Songs from BTS members Jungkook and Jimin, along with groups ENHYPEN, and ILLIT have been added as rhythm game content for Fortnite Festival.

During an interview with ChosunBiz, Epic's senior design director Eric Williamson commented on how Fortnite has been evolving to more than just a game. "K-pop is a powerful cultural asset that connects global fandoms. Fortnite is evolving into a digital cultural hub that integrates music, fashion, and sports, and K-content serves as both an experimental field and a catalyst for this ecosystem," Williamson said.

Heung-min is far from the first gigantic sports star that have crossed over into Fortnite. Recent additions include baseball player Shohei Ohtani. Other notable athletes who have Fortnite skins include LeBron James, Neymar Jr, Harry Kane, Naomi Osaka, Patrick Mahomes, Giannis Antetokounmpo, and Shaquille O'Neal.
